The Lions spent the whole season at the bottom of their division and finished at 2â14. The 2009 season was the first season with the Lions for new head coach [[Jim Schwartz]], and most of his new coaching staff. The Lions introduced new uniforms and logos this year. ==Offseason== ===Repercussions of 2008 season=== {{Main|2008 Detroit Lions season}} On December 29, 2008, the day after the last game of the 0â16 2008 season, Detroit Lions owner [[William Clay Ford, Sr.]] announced head coach [[Rod Marinelli]] had been fired.[http://www.detroitlions.com/news/article-1/William-Clay-Ford-Promotes-Tom-Lewand-to-Team-President-and-Martin-Mayhew-to-General-Manager/8efbb3f4-8d78-4be9-aa17-94388acfe31e Detroit Lions official site William Clay Ford Promotes Tom Lewand to Team President and Martin Mayhew to General Manager] His record with the Lions was 10â38 in three seasons. He also announced: *The promotion of [[Tom Lewand]] to Team President. *The promotion of [[Martin Mayhew]] to General Manager. *The following assistant coaches were not retained: [[Joe Barry]] (Defensive Coordinator), [[Mike Barry (American football)|Mike Barry]] (Assistant Offensive Line) and Jimmy Lake (Secondary). *The contract of [[Joe Cullen]] (Defensive Line) will not be renewed. *The team also announced that [[Jim Colletto]] has been re-assigned to offensive line coach. He ultimately left the team and would be replaced by [[George Yarno]] as offensive line coach. *Additionally, Dave Boller (Assistant Director of Pro Personnel) was not retained. ===New coaching staff=== *On January 15, 2009, the Lions hired [[Jim Schwartz]] as head coach. He spent 10 seasons with the [[Tennessee Titans]], 8 of them as defensive coordinator, helping them compile a 13â3 record and 1st place in the [[AFC South]] in [[2008 Tennessee Titans season|2008]], before being eliminated in the [[NFL playoffs, 2008-09#Divisional playoffs|AFC Divisional playoffs]] by the [[2008 Baltimore Ravens season|Baltimore Ravens]].[http://detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090116/OPINION03/901160357/1004/SPORTS Detroit News January 16, 2009 Lions Pick Schwartz] *On January 21, 2009, the Lions hired veteran coach and defensive coordinator [[Gunther Cunningham]] as defensive coordinator and assistant head coach. Cunningham worked with Schwartz on the Titans from 2001â2003, and has several years of coaching and defensive coordinating experience with the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] and [[Oakland Raiders]].[http://www.detroitlions.com/news/article-1/Lions-Name-Gunther-Cunningham-as-Assistant-Head-CoachDefensive-Coordinator/985900d3-7f4d-48bd-b49f-020e990249b5 Detroit Lions Official Site January 21, 2009 Lions Name Gunther Cunningham as Assistant Head Coach/Defensive Coordinator] *On January 23, 2009, the Lions hired [[Scott Linehan]] as the offensive coordinator. Linehan held the head coaching position of the [[St. Louis Rams]] from 2006â2008 but was fired after losing the first 4 games of the [[2008 St. Louis Rams season|2008 season]]. This is the second time in three years the Lions have turned to a former Rams coach. He also served as the offensive coordinator for the [[Miami Dolphins]] in 2005 and the [[Minnesota Vikings]] for three seasons (2002â2004).[http://www.detroitlions.com/news/article-1/Lions-Name-Scott-Linehan-as-Offensive-Coordinator/04be7ec6-82bc-467f-bc9f-cbf3ee10f9f2 Detroit Lions Official Site January 23, 2009 Lions Name Scott Linehan as Offensive Coordinator] {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background-color: #006DB0; He played on the Super Bowl Champion Pittsburgh Steelers in 2008. ===Corey Smith disappearance=== On March 1, 2009 it was reported that free agent defensive end [[Corey Smith]] (who played for the Lions from 2006â2008) boarded a fishing boat off the Gulf Coast of Florida with former teammate [[Marquis Cooper]] (most recently of the [[Oakland Raiders]]) and former [[South Florida Bulls football|University of South Florida]] players Nick Schuyler and William Blakely on February 28. Smith and Cooper played together on the [[2004 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|Tampa Bay Buccaneers in 2004]]. They did not return as expected and the men and their boat were searched for by the [[U.S. Coast Guard]] for 3 days. The [[National Weather Service]] said waves were about 2 to 4 feet Saturday morning and increased to 3 to 5 feet in the afternoon. Late Saturday night, a small craft advisory was issued, when winds were around 20 knots and waves were up to 7 feet or more.[http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ap-missingboaters-nfl&prov=ap&type=lgns Yahoo! News March 1, 2009 Agent: 2 NFL players among Fla. missing boaters] On March 2, at approximately 1:30 PM, Coast Guard Petty Official James Harless reported that Schuyler had been found alive "clinging to an overturned vessel". He was later diagnosed with [[hypothermia]] and [[dehydration]].[http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/03/02/florida.missing.boaters/index.html CNN.com March 2, 2009 Boater found, NFL players still missing] On March 3, the Coast Guard called off the search. Later that day, the Lions released this statement:{{cite web|title= Detroit Lions reaction to news that Coast Guard will cease search and rescue efforts for Corey Smith, Will Bleakley and Marquis Cooper|url=http://www.detroitlions.com/document_display.cfm?document_id=482242|work=|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgoziC9v|archivedate=2009-06-21|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-05-11}} {{Cquote|Todayâs news is a sobering reminder about how truly precious and fragile life can be. We will continue to pray for a miracle, though we fully understand and respect the decision of the Coast Guard. We were thrilled yesterday with the news of Nickâs rescue, and it gave all of us hope that Corey, Will and Marquis would also be found alive. While we still have that hope, we have begun to cope with the grim reality of this sad and tragic situation. We cannot adequately express our heartfelt appreciation to the Coast Guard and all the Florida authorities involved in the rescue mission. Their heroic efforts saved at least one life, and we know they did everything possible for Corey, Will and Marquis. We also want to thank everyone across the country for their expressions of support. We ask that you join us as we continue to pray for Corey, Will, Marquis and their families.|200|200|Detroit Lions Press Release, March 3, 2009}} A private search led by the families of the still missing men began on March 4.[http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/03/03/florida.missing.boaters/index.html CNN.com March 4, 2009 Coast Guard suspends search for NFL players, friend] The Lions have also announced that Smith's jersey number, 93, will not be issued for the 2009 season.{{cite web|title= Yahoo! Sports March 21, 2009 In Smithâs memory, no Lion will wear 93 this fall|url=http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=Av02IJjMbMLyrB4UsXEW.QRDubYF?slug=ap-missingboaters-nfl&prov=ap&type=lgns|work=|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgp09LEX|archivedate=2009-06-21|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-05-11}} The Lions also wore a 93 on the back of their helmets. ===2009 NFL Draft=== {{Main|2009 NFL Draft}} With their league worst record in 2008, the Lions secured the #1 overall pick in the 2009 NFL Draft. Detroit also had the #20 overall pick in the first round, which they received from the [[Dallas Cowboys]] as part of the [[Roy Williams (wide receiver)|Roy Williams]] trade in 2008. The trade also gave them additional picks in the 3rd and 6th rounds. The Lions traded its 2009 fourth-round selection (101st overall) and its 2008 third-round selection (111th overall, which was traded to Cleveland) to Dallas for its 2008 third-round selection (92nd overall, used to select [[Cliff Avril]]). The Lions selected [[Georgia Bulldogs football|University of Georgia]] [[quarterback]] [[Matthew Stafford]] for the #1 overall pick. [http://espn.go.com/nfl/boxscore?gameId=290920008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Vikings at Lions week 2] ===Week 3: vs. Washington Redskins=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Redskins |R1=0||R2=0||R3=7||R4=7||RT=14 |Home='''Lions''' |H1=7||H2=6||H3=0||H4=6|HT=19 |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 40,896 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]] and [[Brian Billick]] ([[NFL_on_television#Blackout_policies|blacked out]] locally).[http://freep.com/article/20090924/SPORTS01/90924043/1049/Lions--home-game-Sunday-blacked-out-locally Detroit Free Press September 24, 2009 Lions' home game Sunday blacked out locally]{{Dead link|date=December 2009}} }} In week 3, the Lions hosted the [[2009 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]]. [http://www.nfl.com/videos/detroit-lions/09000d5d812f39a9/Lions-19-Redskins-14 NFL.com Week 3 highlight video Redskins at Lions] [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Katie Holmes]] were in attendance as guests of Redskins owner [[Daniel Snyder|Dan Snyder]]. ===Week 4: at Chicago Bears=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=14||R2=7||R3=0||R4=3||RT=24 |Home='''Bears''' |H1=7||H2=14||H3=13||H4=14||HT=48 |stadium= Soldier Field, Chicago, Illinois |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 64 Â°F (partly cloudy) |attendance= 62,192 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]], [[Brian Billick]], & [[Chris Myers]] }} In week 4, the Lions flew to [[Chicago, Illinois|The Windy City]] for a NFC North duel with the [[2009 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291004003 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at Bears week 4] ===Week 5: vs Pittsburgh Steelers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Steelers''' |R1=7||R2=14||R3=7||R4=0||RT= |Home=Lions |H1=6||H2=7||H3=0||H4=7|HT= |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 59,333 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} In week 5, the Lions hosted the defending Super Bowl Champion [[2009 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]]. On a positive note, the Lions defense recorded 5 sacks.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/boxscore?gameId=291018009 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at Packers week 6] ===Week 8: vs St. Louis Rams=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Rams''' |R1=3||R2=7||R3=0||R4=7||RT= |Home=Lions |H1=0||H2=2||H3=0||H4=8|HT= |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 40,857 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]] & [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] (blacked out locally) [http://freep.com/article/20091029/SPORTS01/91029038/1049/Lions-game-to-be-blacked-out Detroit Free Press October 29, 2009 Lions game on Sunday to be blacked out]{{Dead link|date=December 2009}} }} In week 8, the Lions hosted the [[2009 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]]. The Rams took the lead near the end though with a 25 yard run by [[Steven Jackson]].[http://scores.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291101008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Rams at Lions week 8] This would be the Rams' only victory of the season, preventing them from duplicating the Lions dubious accomplishment of the previous season. ===Week 9: at Seattle Seahawks=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=17||R2=0||R3=0||R4=3||RT= |Home='''Seahawks''' |H1=0||H2=13||H3=9||H4=10|HT= |stadium= Qwest Field, Seattle Washington |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 48 Â°F, cloudy |attendance= 67,003 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]], [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} In week 9, the Lions traveled to [[Seattle, Washington]] to take on the [[2009 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks]]. The Seahawks sealed their win with a 61 yard interception for a TD by [[Josh Wilson (American football)|Josh Wilson]].[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291108026 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at Seahawks week 9] ===Week 10: at Minnesota Vikings=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=0||R2=3||R3=7||R4=0||RT= |Home='''Vikings''' |H1=3||H2=7||H3=7||H4=10|HT= |stadium= Mall of America Field, Minneapolis, Minnesota |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 63,854 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Sam Rosen (sportscaster)|Sam Rosen]], [[Tim Ryan (American football)|Tim Ryan]] & [[Chris Myers]] }} In week 10, the Lions traveled to [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] for a rematch with NFC North foes the Minnesota Vikings. The Vikings sealed their win with a TD and field goal in the 4th. First a 8 yard TD catch by [[Jeff Dugan]] from [[Brett Favre]], and finally a 35 yard field goal.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291115016 ESPN.com NFL Recap Week 10 Lions at Vikings] ===Week 11: vs. Cleveland Browns=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=24||R2=3||R3=2||R4=8||RT= |Home='''Lions''' |H1=10||H2=14||H3=7||H4=7|HT= |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 43,170 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Don Criqui]] & [[Randy Cross]] (blacked out locally)[http://detnews.com/article/20091119/SPORTS0101/911190467/1126/sports0101/No-local-TV-for-Lions-Browns Detroit News November 19, 2009 No local TV for Lions-Browns] }} In week 11, the Lions hosted the [[2009 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] in a non-conference shootout. The Browns built a big lead in the first quarter. They scored first with a 44 yard field goal by [[Phil Dawson]]. The Lions tied it up with a 31 yard Jason Hanson field goal of their own. Cleveland then scored 3 consecutive touchdowns via passes from [[Brady Quinn]]: a 59 yard catch from [[Mohamed Massaquoi]], a 40-yard snare by [[Chansi Stuckey]], and a 4-yard reception by [[Joshua Cribbs]]. The Lions then responded with 3 consecutive TD passes of their own from Matthew Stafford: a 26-yard grab by Aaron Brown, a 25 yard catch by Kevin Smith, and a 75-yard catch and run TD for Calvin Johnson. The Browns responded with a 29 yard field goal just before halftime. In the 3rd quarter Will Heller of the Lions caught a 1 yard TD pass. The Browns received a safety when Stafford was tackled in his own end zone and called for intentional grounding. The Browns took the lead back with a 2 yard TD catch by [[Michael Gaines]]. The Lions then attempted to regained the lead with just under 2 minutes to go. After throwing an interception, they stopped the Browns on 4th and 5. Then they drove 88 yards. With 2 seconds left, Matt Stafford threw a pass into the end zone which was intercepted, but it was called back on a pass interference penalty, giving the Lions one more play with no time left on the clock. Although Stafford was brutally hit by two Browns defenders on the play, and suffered what turned out to be a major shoulder separation of his non-throwing arm, he told the coaches he wanted to return for the final play (pleading to coaches "If you need me to throw the ball, I can throw the ball") and was allowed to go back in. He then threw a touchdown to Brandon Pettigrew, and Jason Hanson tacked on the extra point for the win. Matt Stafford became the youngest QB to throw 5 touchdown passes in a game since the [[AFL-NFL merger]] in 1970. He also set a record for passing yards in a game by a rookie with 422.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291122008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Browns at Lions week 11] For his performance, Stafford won NFC Offensive Player of the Week and Pepsi Rookie of the Week.[http://www.detroitlions.com/news/article-1/Stafford-Named-NFC-Offensive-Player-of-the-Week/f8de6f01-97b1-48ed-89aa-6bf31d9a1c8d Detroit Lions.com November 24, 2009 â Stafford Named NFC Offensive Player of the Week][http://www.detroitlions.com/news/article-1/QB-Matthew-Stafford-Voted-Week-11-Pepsi-NFL-Rookie-of-the-Week/7e2feed7-e1f6-47bc-b11a-70f3d1299275 Detroit Lions Official Site November 27, 2009 QB Matthew Stafford Voted Week 11 Pepsi NFL Rookie of the Week] The game was made into an [[NFL Films|NFL Film]], with [[Matt Stafford]] mic'ed up. It was shown on [[NFL Network]]'s ''[[NFL Replay]]'' and ''Wired for Sound'' as well as [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s ''[[Inside the NFL]]''. The company's founder [[Steve Sabol]] said the Lions' game winning drive was the most dramatic film he has seen in over 30 years. ===Week 12: vs. Green Bay Packers ([[Thanksgiving Classic]])=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=0||R2=13||R3=14||R4=7||RT=34 |Home=Lions |H1=7||H2=0||H3=0||H4=5|HT=12 |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 12:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 57,383 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]], National TV |TVAnnouncers=[[Joe Buck]], [[Troy Aikman]] & [[Pam Oliver]] }} For their 70th annual [[Thanksgiving Classic]] game, the Lions hosted a rematch with division rivals the [[2009 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]]. Detroit got an early lead when Matt Stafford threw a 1 yard TD pass to Calvin Johnson, the only Lions score of the first half. The Packers responded with a TD of their own, a 7 yard toss to [[Donald Lee (American football)|Donald Lee]]. The Packers then kicked 2 field goals: first a 20 yarder and just before halftime a 25 yarder. The Packers scored 2 touchdowns in the 3rd quarter. First a 7 yard catch by [[Donald Driver]], then a 21 yard catch by [[James Jones (wide receiver)|James Jones]]. The Lions picked up a safety when the Packers fumbled the ball in their own end zone in the fourth quarter. They then kicked a 22 yard field goal. The Packers sealed their win when [[Charles Woodson]] intercepted a Matt Stafford pass and ran it back 38 yards for a touchdown. The Thanksgiving Day losing streak for the Lions is now six, the longest in franchise history.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/boxscore?gameId=291126008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Packers at Lions Week 12] With the loss combined with the [[2009 Philadelphia Eagles season|Eagles]] win over the [[2009 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]], the Lions were officially eliminated from postseason contention. This would also become the Packers' 9th straight victory over the Lions, dating back to the second game between the teams in the 2005 season. ===Week 13: at Cincinnati Bengals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=7||R2=0||R3=0||R4=6||RT= |Home='''Bengals''' |H1=0||H2=17||H3=3||H4=3|HT= |stadium= Paul Brown Stadium, Cincinnati, Ohio |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 34 Â°F, partly cloudy |attendance= 62,545 |referee= [[Tony Corrente]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]], [[Brian Billick]] & [[Laura Okmin]] }} In week 13, the Lions traveled to [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] for a non-conference contest with the [[2009 Cincinnati Bengals season|Cincinnati Bengals]]. Detroit got an early lead in the first quarter with a 54 yard catch and run by Calvin Johnson. The Bengals tied it up in the second when [[Jonathan Fanene]] caught a tipped Matt Stafford pass and ran it back 45 yards for a touchdown. Cincinnati then took the lead and didn't give it back when [[Chad Ochocinco]] caught a 36 yard TD. The Bengals closed out the first half with a 44 yard field goal by [[Shayne Graham]]. In the second half the Bengals scored 2 more field goals, from 39 and 23 yards respectively. The Lions scored the game's final points late in the 4th quarter with a 2 yard run by Kevin Smith. The Lions went for a 2 point conversion but failed.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291206004 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at Bengals Week 13] ===Week 14: at Baltimore Ravens=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=0||R2=3||R3=0||R4=0||RT= |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=3||H2=17||H3=21||H4=7|HT= |stadium= M&T Bank Stadium, Baltimore, Maryland |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 34 Â°F, rain |attendance= 70,673 |referee= [[Don Carey (official)|Don Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Chris Myers]] & [[Tim Ryan (American football)|Tim Ryan]] }} In week 14, the Lions traveled to rainy [[Baltimore, Maryland]] for a non-conference duel with the [[2009 Baltimore Ravens season|Baltimore Ravens]]. Baltimore lead for almost the entire game. They scored first late in the first quarter with a 38 yard field goal by [[Billy Cundiff]]. They added to their lead with a 62 yard catch and run TD by [[Derrick Mason]] from [[Joe Flacco]]. The Lions scored their only points of the game near the end of the second quarter with a 22 yard Jason Hanson field goal. A minute later the Ravens responded with a 59 yard rushing TD by [[Ray Rice]]. Baltimore finished out the first half with a 25 yard field goal. In the second half the Ravens scored 4 consecutive touchdowns. First a [[Le'Ron McClain]] 3 yard run. Then 2 by [[Willis McGahee]]: first a 8 yard run, then a 19 yard run. In the fourth quarter, the Ravens capped off their huge victory when [[Troy Smith]] ran in a TD from 15 yards. Lions backup quarterback Daunte Culpepper completed less than half of his passes (16 for 34) and threw 2 interceptions.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?&gameId=291213033 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at Ravens week 14] ===Week 15: vs. Arizona Cardinals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Cardinals''' |R1=7||R2=10||R3=0||R4=14||RT= |Home=Lions |H1=0||H2=0||H3=17||H4=7|HT= |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 40,577 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Chris Myers]] & [[Tim Ryan (American football)|Tim Ryan]] (blacked out locally) [http://freep.com/article/20091217/SPORTS01/91217042/1049/sports01/Lions-will-be-blacked-out-again-Sunday Detroit Free Press December 17, 2009 Lions will be blacked out again Sunday] }} In week 15, the Lions hosted the defending the NFC Champion [[2009 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]]. Then near halftime a 1 yard rush by [[Tim Hightower]]. After his unproductive first half (6 for 12 and only 64 yards passing and an interception) Lions backup quarterback Daunte Culpepper was replaced by third stringer Drew Stanton who breathed some life into the offense. First though came an interception and 100 yard Lions TD run by Louis Delmas, a tie for the third longest interception TD in team history. A few minutes later Detroit's Maurice Morris ran in a career high 64 yard TD. In the 4th quarter, the Cardinals responded with a 18 yard [[Beanie Wells|Chris Wells]] TD run. The Cardinals sealed their victory though with just under 2 minutes left when [[Anquan Boldin]] caught a 5 yard TD pass. The Lions attempted to tie it back up soon after but were stopped on 4th and 1.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291220008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Cardinals at Lions week 15] ===Week 16: at San Francisco 49ers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=3||R2=0||R3=0||R4=3||RT= |Home='''49ers''' |H1=3||H2=3||H3=14||H4=0|HT= |stadium= Candlestick Park, San Francisco, California |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 55 Â°F, sunny |attendance= 69,732 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] }} For their last road game of the season, in week 16 the Lions traveled west to [[San Francisco, California]] to play the [[2009 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]]. The Lions took an early lead midway through the 1st quarter with a 27 yard Jason Hanson field goal. The 49ers tied it up at the end of the 1st quarter with a 33 yard field goal by [[Ricky Schmitt]]. The only score of the 2nd quarter was a 39 yard 49ers field goal just before halftime. In the 3rd quarter came 2 San Francisco TD's. First a 2 yard catch by [[Vernon Davis]], then a 1 yard run by [[Frank Gore]]. The Lions kicked another field goal late in the 4th quarter from 38 yards out. The Lions road losing streak now stands at 20.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=291227025 ESPN.com NFL Recap Lions at 49ers week 16] ===Week 17: vs Chicago Bears=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bears''' |R1=3||R2=10||R3=7||R4=17||RT= |Home=Lions |H1=3||H2=7||H3=3||H4=10|HT= |stadium= Ford Field, Detroit, Michigan |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= none (domed stadium) |attendance= 56,677 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Chris Myers]], [[Trent Green]], and [[Jennifer Hammond]] }} For their season finale, the Lions hosted a rematch with division rivals the [[2009 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]]. The Bears started the scoring in the first quarter with a 44 yard field goal by [[Robbie Gould]]. The Lions responded with a 42 yard field goal of their own. Then in the second quarter the Bears kicked another field goal, from 28 yards out. The Lions then took the lead with a 12 yard Bryant Johnson TD catch. The Bears took it back just before halftime with a 7 yard [[Greg Olsen (American football)|Greg Olsen]] TD catch. In the third quarter the Bears added to their lead with a [[Devin Aromashodu]] 9 yard TD catch. The Lions responded with a 48 yard field goal. Later, in the fourth quarter, the Lions tied it up with a 5 yard Calvin Johnson TD catch. The Bears took the lead back though with a [[Desmond Clark]] 1 yard TD catch. The Lions then scored their final points of the season, a 32 yard field goal. The Bears responded with another Devin Aromashodu TD catch, this one from 12 yards. The Bears closed out the scoring with a 34 yard field goal.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=300103008 ESPN.com NFL Recap Bears at Lions week 17] The loss allowed the Lions to clinch the second overall selection in the [[2010 NFL Draft]] behind the [[2009 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]], who finished 1â15. Coincidentally, the Rams' lone victory came at Detroit's expense in week 8. == Local TV Blackouts == In the 2009 season, the Lions had four of their 8 home games televised on local TV. The Lions sold out their home opener against the Vikings, as well as a week 5 match up against the Steelers, the Thanksgiving Classic against Green Bay, and their season finale against the Bears. Both of the Lions wins in 2009 were blacked out on local television (the Detroit, Flint/Tri-Cities, Lansing/Jackson and Toledo markets) because the game didn't sell out by the 72 hour deadline. In the games that Detroit didn't sell out, the attendances were announced at just over 40,000 and quite often, the stadium looked only half full.
